stem: A 5-week-old infant is brought with 2 days of projectile, non-bilious vomiting. The infant is lethargic with sunked fontanelles. An olive-shaped mass is felt in the RUQ. Complete the bowtie to guide care.

actions.text: Maintain NPO and initiate IV fluids (D5NS + K)
Apply a warm compress to the RUQ mass

rationale.correct: Projectile vomiting + Olive-shaped mass = Pyloric Stenosis. Priority is Correction of dehydration/alkalosis (IV fluids) and surgical repair. Monitoring focus is fluid/electrolyte balance (especially hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis) and I&Os.
rationale.incorrect: Feedings will be vomited and risk aspiration. The mass does not need local compresses. While bowel sounds are present, they aren't the primary stabilization indicator.
clinicalPearls: Pyloric stenosis typically occurs between 2 and 8 weeks of life.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: If it's non-bilious (no green), it's above the duodenum (Pyloric). If it's bilious (green), it's below the duodenum (Obstruction).

mnemonic.title: HPS
mnemonic.expansion:
H = Hypertrophic
P = Pyloric
S = Stenosis

Key Actions: Maintain NPO and initiate IV fluids (D5NS + K); Prepare for surgical pyloromyotomy
Key Monitoring: Electrolytes (Chloride and Potassium); I&O and daily weight

Monitoring focus is fluid/electrolyte balance (especially hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis) and I&Os. Pyloric stenosis typically occurs between 2 and 8 weeks of life.

reviewUnits.heading: Testing Trap â€” Vomit color
reviewUnits.body: If it's non-bilious (no green), it's above the duodenum (Pyloric). If it's bilious (green), it's below the duodenum (Obstruction).

reviewUnits.heading: Priority Interventions for Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis
reviewUnits.body: The priority nursing interventions are: Maintain NPO and initiate IV fluids (D5NS + K); Prepare for surgical pyloromyotomy. Monitor: Electrolytes (Chloride and Potassium); I&O and daily weight. Feedings will be vomited and risk aspiration. The mass does not need local compresses. While bowel sounds are present, they aren't the primary stabilization indicator.
